doc.title: JPM | BACK TO SCHOOL-Bigger Buffer,better buoyancy?? Plus Prudential, Shell & Bunzl
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-31/JPM BACK TO SCHOOL- Bigger Bufferbetter buoyancy Plus Prudential Shell BunzlJPM BACK TO SCHOOL- Bigger Bufferbetter buoy_2025-08-31

passages.text: This week saw a new high in UK tax speculation. Two months out from the Budget feels like prime time for semi- informed articles on the latest thinking at the Treasury. This week press coverage mooted National Insurance on landlord's 'unearned' income, Bank Taxes, lower allowances on primary residences for IHT and a landfill tax. Even mention of these potential taxes has a pernicious impact on confidence. Who would rush to buy a BTL property now?

Gambling taxes and extending the freeze on personal tax allowances feel like racing certainties. But the scope of our fiscal gap remains unclear. A thin buffer is damaging in itself - the coffers are always vulnerable. The article below argues the Chancellor may need to raise taxes even further in order to increase the buffer. A bigger buffer might help Gilt markets and boost economic confidence. The argument about addressing this hiatus is hard to contradict.. But the tax burden it entails may deliver a nasty shock. In that context the articles about Bank Taxes felt more credible. Perhaps the first of the 'difficult choices' facing the UK is which tax needs to rise to increase the buffer.

In this article Bloomberg economists argue for a larger fiscal buffer. Few would argue the current structure is helping confidence. The twice annual OBR outputs drive cycles of speculation about the next tax raise. A larger buffer might reduce Gilts 'idiosyncratic premium' and help the economy by removing uncertainty. The table below shows a history of UK fiscal headroom in 2029/30 real terms. The current level is clearly far lower than through history. Rachel Reeves ' fiscal rules plus record sovereign debt makes a credible buffer more important now than in living memory.
I had the opportunity to meet the management team at Prudential via Zoom. As a relative newcomer, it was helpful to hear the story direct. Below is simplistic summary...

Pru feels like a structural growth story with management impetus at a potent juncture. Growth in New Business over the last decade as accrued a sizeable Embedded Value which is now being released as cash flow as those policies mature. crystallizes into cash flow and rising shareholder returns. The shares start on x11 pe at today's \(\) 34bn\(mkt cap. The group is returning c.\) \ \(1.25bn\) pa. Split between dividend - c. \(\) 700m\(growing at +10\%\(cagr - and SBB -\) \ \(550m\) average across 26 & 27. A total return 'yield' of \(3.7\%\)

Additionally, Pru are monetising their share of Indian Asset Manager JV with ICICI. It's a long process but JPM value the c. \(12\%\) slated for sale at c. \(\) 1bn\(. The whole stake therefore might be worth\) \ \(4bn\) . This is a significant stock of value - \(12\%\) of today's mkt cap.

The group is building credibility by delivering sustainable growth via selective new business Emerging cashflow from maturing book facilitates SBBs to augment the shareholder algorithm. These trends seem long- dated as the group moves through the next few quarters aftertion may start to settle on the trajectory of growth and returns beyond 2027...
1) Growth - Large & growing TAM driven by structurally underserved markets
2) Cashflow – When potential is realised...A decade of new business starts to cascade into surplus cash.
3) Returns – Cash generation is improving - Rising Gross OFSG now drops through to sustainable FCF for shareholders.
Europe Specialist Sales JPM | BACK TO SCHOOL- Bigger Buffer, better buoyancy?? Plus Prudential, Shell & Bunzl 31 August 2025
4) Delivery on 2027 targets...The group is nearing delivery of both long-term cagr targets...+10% Gross Free Surplus (Cash) Generation & +15-20% Growth in New Business Profit (NBP)
3) SHELL- Is the most resilient oil stock in Europe...Low leverage and best-in-class oil price sensitivity
Figure 13: Cash return; fixed/variable %CFFO policies see flex manifest through buybacks with divs secure down to \$50/bbl

Prior to that we published a Shell/BP M&A deep dive during May, assessing the merits of a combination through proforma modelling and an analysis of global supermajor complementarity. At a \(20\%\) price premium and mid- range \(4\%\) of equity value synergies (\\(3.5bn pa post- tax), we estimated moderate rather than compelling accretion to Shell's key >+10% FCF/sh CAGR 2030 metric across financing scenarios. A deeper value proposition is required...particularly given the gearing and execution risks. To derive a premium \(\geq 15\%\) we estimated cash component, outsized synergies (2X our base case) and/or a BP price point \(20\%\) lower would be needed.

Our analysis presented pro forma financials under two financing scenarios, 30/70 cash/equity and \(100\%\) equity, - Shell's FCF/share guidance is \(10\% +\) cgar. We modelled a modest improvement to \(+13 - 14\%\) CAGR under 30/70 cash/equity but no more than in line with the \(10\%\) threshold at \(100\%\) equity. - While superior scale is undoubted, Wood Mackenzie data indicates a combination wouldn't necessarily convincingly enhance oil production sustainability beyond 2030 (- \(2\%\) CAGR 2027- 33).

At the time of publishing BP shares had underperformed Shell \(15\%\) 1Y and \(>25\%\) 3Y but had not reversed nearly as significantly on EV metrics owing to rising net debt and EPS revisions had also lagged. On standalone 2026e valuation screens at \(65 / \mathrm{bbl}\) Brent, BP screened richer than Shell on our FCF yield estimates and no more than broadly in line on EV/DACF (pre- capex) and P/E multiples.
Figure 15: Valuation and performance; BP standalone multiples/yields not at a clear discount to Shell...despite a greater debt burden
3) BUNZL - A step back towards regaining their multiple

Our Take: Bunzl published its full 1H25 results this morning with organic growth (1H: \(- 0.2\%\) trading day adjusted) and operating margin (1H: \(7.0\%\) ) broadly in- line with the guidance provided in the pre- close statement at the end of June. One of the key focus into results was the North America business, which Bunzl delivered \(- 1.2\%\) organic growth for the first half (vs. JPMc/Bloomberg cons. \(- 1.5\% / - 2.0\%\) ). Importantly, management highlighted that early indicators of the actions taken are positive and that it remains positive for business wins in the second half. Tariff- related price increases have also been implemented in 2Q, and Bunzl expects to see further increases in the remainder of the year. With FY25 guidance reiterated and Bunzl commenting that trading in July has been consistent with expectations for 2H, we expect limited changes to consensus at this point. That said, we have increased our full year EPS estimate by \(1\%\) to factor in the resumed share buyback (f86m remaining of the previously announced f200m 2025 share buyback). Call at 09:30am UKT.

1) H1 revenue growth at AER was \(0.8\%\) (4.2% CER) vs. guidance given at the pre-close for \(1\%\) at AER and \(4\%\) at CER. Organically, revenue declined by \(-0.2\%\) trading day adjusted \((-0.7\%)\) not adjusted for trading days) vs. guidance for around flat. Q1 revenue was down \(-0.9\%\) organically, implying \(c.0.5\%\) day-adjusted in Q2. H1 EBITA of f404.5m (a \(7.0\%\) margin) was in line with JPMc (f404m) and Bloomberg consensus (f406m) and in line with guidance for margin at around \(7\%\) . 
2) Divisionally, organic growth declined \(-1.2\%\) in NA, while CE was down \(-0.4\%\) . UK&I and RoW revenues were up \(0.3\%\) and \(5.6\%\) , respectively, both organically. 
3) Margin. H1 margin of \(7.0\%\) was down 100bps y/y, with NA down 100bps, CE down 100bps, UK&I down 100bps and RoW down 60bps y/y. 
4) Cash and leverage. Cash conversion was \(97\%\) (100% in 1H24) with ND/EBITDA at 1.9x (2.1x incl. lease liabilities). 
5) M&A. Five acquisitions announced year-to-date, including Quindesur and Gisa announced today, bringing the total committed spend to f120m year-to-date. This compares to the average annual committed spend over the four years to 31 Dec 2024 of c. f550m. Management highlighted that the pipeline remains active.

6) Share buyback resumed.Bunzl resumed its share buyback program to complete the remaining £86m of the previously announced £200m 2025 share buyback in the second half of the year. As a result, Bunzl expects leverage to be towards the lower end of its target range of 2.0 to 2.5x at the end of the year, after potential acquisition spend and a completed 2025 share buyback programme.
7) Dividend. The proposed interim dividend is 20.2p, up \(0.5\%\) y/y.

Outlook & Guidance: Bunzl reiterated its FY25 guidance and expects (a) 'moderate' constant currency revenue growth, driven by announced acquisitions and broadly flat underlying revenue (vs. JPMc -0.4%, Bloomberg consensus -0.6% FY25 organic growth); and (b) operating margin to be 'moderately below 8.0%' (vs. JPMc 7.7%, Bloomberg consensus 7.6% FY25 EBITA margin). Bunzl also expects net adjusted finance expense in 2025 to be c.£120m and the full year effective tax rate to be around 26.0%.
Changes to estimates: We leave our estimates broadly unchanged, but factor in the resumed share buyback which results in a \(1\%\) increase in our 2025/26 EPS forecast.
Valuation: Bunzl trades on a 2026E P/E of 12.8x and \(7.8\%\) FCF yield.
